steps.title: Rinse fully ripe figs.
steps.content: Rinse fully ripe figs. The best indication that a fig is fully ripe is when it falls to the ground. Rinse the figs with cool water to remove dirt and other debris, then pat them dry with a dishcloth or paper towel.

steps.title: Cut the figs in half.
steps.content: Cut the figs in half. Use a paring knife to cut the figs in half from stem to tip on a cutting board. Cutting the figs in half will help them dry more quickly.

steps.title: Lay them on a wire or wooden rack covered with cheesecloth.
steps.content: Lay them on a wire or wooden rack covered with cheesecloth. Put a layer of cheesecloth on top of any wooden or wire rack, such as those intended for cooling or dehydrating. In order to dry properly, the figs need airflow from above and below, so don't use a solid surface like a baking sheet. Place the figs cut-side up on the cheesecloth. Alternatively, you could put whole figs on wooden skewers and hang them in the sun, using clothespins to attach the skewers to branches or to a clothesline. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Cover the figs with cheesecloth.
steps.content: Cover the figs with cheesecloth. This will protect them from insects as they dry. Tuck the cheesecloth tightly around the drying rack, securing it with tape if necessary, to make sure it won't come loose. [2] X Research source If you hung up your figs instead, you won't be able to protect them with the cheesecloth.

steps.title: Place the rack in full sunlight during the day.
steps.content: Place the rack in full sunlight during the day. This method works best when it is very dry and hot outside. Don't place the figs in the shade, or they won't dry as quickly and may spoil before they're properly preserved. You'll need to bring them in each evening so they don't get spoiled by dew.

steps.title: Return the figs to the sun for 2 to 3 days.
steps.content: Return the figs to the sun for 2 to 3 days. Each morning, turn the figs over so they dry evenly on all sides and then place them back outside in the sunlight. The figs are ready when the outside feels leathery and no juice can be seen on the inside when squeezed. If the figs remain a little sticky, you can finish them in the oven.

steps.title: Store the dried figs in airtight containers in the fridge or freezer.
steps.content: Store the dried figs in airtight containers in the fridge or freezer. Tupperware or Ziploc bags are both options for storing your dried figs. They'll last several months in the fridge, or up to 3 years in the freezer.

steps.title: Preheat your oven to 140° F (60° C).
steps.content: Preheat your oven to 140° F (60° C). This should be the lowest setting your oven has, which is necessary to dry the figs at a low, even temperature. Drying them at a higher temperature would result in cooked figs . [3] X Research source If your oven doesn't heat to such a low temperature, set it at the lowest possible temperature and keep the oven door partially open.

steps.title: Rinse the figs thoroughly with water.
steps.content: Rinse the figs thoroughly with water. Carefully trim away the stems as well as any damaged parts and pat them dry with a paper towel or dishcloth. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Cut the figs in half.
steps.content: Cut the figs in half. Use a paring knife to slice the figs from stem to tip, lengthwise, on a cutting board. If they are particularly large, cut them in quarters. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Lay them cut-side-up on an oven-safe rack.
steps.content: Lay them cut-side-up on an oven-safe rack. Be sure to use a rack with ventilation holes, so that the figs dry from below and above. Using a regular baking pan will result in figs that don't dry evenly. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Put the figs in the oven for up to 36 hours.
steps.content: Put the figs in the oven for up to 36 hours. Prop the oven door open slightly to allow the moisture to escape and prevent the figs from getting too hot and cooking instead of drying. If you don't want to leave the oven on continuously, you can turn it off halfway through, then turn it back on if necessary. Be sure to turn the figs occasionally during the drying process. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Allow the figs to cool completely before storing them.
steps.content: Allow the figs to cool completely before storing them. The figs are done drying when the outsides are leathery and no juice can be seen on the inside when you split one open. Remove them from the oven and let them cool completely before placing them in airtight containers, like Ziploc bags. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Put airtight containers full of dried figs in the fridge or freezer.
steps.content: Put airtight containers full of dried figs in the fridge or freezer. You can freeze figs for up to 3 years. Or, you can keep them in the fridge for several months.

steps.title: Turn the dehydrator to the fruit setting.
steps.content: Turn the dehydrator to the fruit setting. If your dehydrator doesn't have a fruit setting, turn it 135° F (57° C). [9] X Research source

steps.title: Rinse the figs and cut them in quarters.
steps.content: Rinse the figs and cut them in quarters. Rinse the figs in cool water, then dry them with a dishcloth. Use a paring knife to remove the stems and cut the figs in quarters on a cutting board. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Place them skin-side-down on the dehydrator trays.
steps.content: Place them skin-side-down on the dehydrator trays. Make sure to leave some room in between the fig pieces so air can circulate around them. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Dehydrate them for 6-8 hours.
steps.content: Dehydrate them for 6-8 hours. The amount of time will depend on the climate in your area as well as the size of the figs. Check them after 8 hours to see if they are dry to the touch, but still pliable and chewy. If so, they're done. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Remove the trays and allow the figs to cool.
steps.content: Remove the trays and allow the figs to cool. Once the figs are done, carefully remove the trays from the dehydrator and place them on a heat-resistant surface. Let them cool completely before storing them. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Store the dried figs in the fridge or freezer in airtight containers.
steps.content: Store the dried figs in the fridge or freezer in airtight containers. Put the dried figs in Tupperware containers or Ziploc bags. They'll keep in the freezer for up to 3 years or in the fridge for several months.
